required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Early Academic Achievement and Intervention Response: Role of Executive Function

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock: Despite the fact that a substantial number of school age children struggle with both reading and math acquisition, the brain mechanisms of the overlapping aspects of reading and math skills, thought in part to be linked via executive functions (EF), have not been unpacked. This project will use a longitudinal design, following children from Kindergarten through 1st grade, to understand how the brain networks associated with reading, math, and EF interact to predict academic outcomes and, in those who struggle academically, intervention response.

detailed_description.textblock:
This longitudinal study will be conducted with 260 Kindergartners, staggered across multiple cohorts, who are followed through 1st grade. There will be three time points of testing for each cohort: fall of Kindergarten, spring of Kindergarten, and in the fall of 1st grade.
After the third testing time point, in the fall of 1st grade, the bottom 1/3 of readers in the sample will be selected to participate in the intervention arm of the study. These students will be randomly placed in one of two arms: business-as-usual, in which children receive no additional instruction; or the reading intervention condition, in which they receive 20 hours of 1:1 reading intervention over 6 weeks. Children in both sub-sample arms are assessed again after tutoring is complete, in the spring of 1st grade.
Neuroimaging through magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) will occur as part of study participation in conjunction with testing at fall of Kindergarten, fall of 1st grade, and spring of 1st grade time points.

primary_outcome.measure: Woodcock Johnson Tests of Achievement, Fourth Edition (WJ-IV)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, at study entry (Fall of Kindergarten)
primary_outcome.description: WJ-IV Letter Word Identification, Word Attack, and Passage Comprehension subtests will be administered in order to assess letter and word recognition accuracy, decoding accuracy and reading comprehension. WJ-IV Calculation and Applied Problems will be administered to assess number identification, basic numeracy skills, and math problem solving. To assess whether cognitive and/or neural metrics of executive function and neural metrics of academic achievement predict academic ability at the same time point.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Woodcock Johnson Tests of Achievement, Fourth Edition (WJ-IV)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, at study entry (Fall of Kindergarten); and approximately 1 year after baseline (Fall of 1st Grade)
primary_outcome.description: Change from baseline in reading (as measured by WJ-IV Letter Word Identification, Word Attack, and Passage Comprehension subtests) and math (as measured by WJ-IV Calculation and Applied Problems subtests).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Woodcock Johnson Tests of Achievement, Fourth Edition (WJ-IV)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately 1 year after baseline (Fall of 1st Grade); and approximately 1 year 3 months after baseline (Spring of 1st Grade)
primary_outcome.description: Change from pre-intervention testing to post-intervention testing in reading (as measured by WJ-IV Letter Word Identification, Word Attack, and Passage Comprehension subtests) and math (as measured by WJ-IV Calculation and Applied Problems subtests).

arm_group.description: 20 hours of one-on-one reading tutoring administered over 6 weeks

intervention.description: 20 hours of 1:1 reading tutoring intervention over 6 weeks
